newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland to relax technology import barriers in 1998.
newsitem.headline: Poland to relax technology import barriers in 1998.

text.p: Poland will begin to gradually phase out customs duties on information technology products next year under an international agreement it signed earlier in May, Economy Minister Wieslaw Kaczmarek said on Tuesday.
Kaczmarek told a news conference that fully assembled computers would be the longest protected product and duties on them would be scrapped in 2002.
"We will lower protection barriers in four stages. The first reduction will take place on January 1, 1998," he said.

Next year, Poland will halve tariffs on most of the 300 technology products which currently attract duty, said Stefan Kaminski, president of the Electronics and Telecommunications Chamber of Commerce. He said that importers would no longer pay duty on microchips, transistors and diodes.

Kaczamrek said that Poland, just as other countries which signed a pact to scrap tariffs in the booming industry earlier this year, will end customs duties for all technology products in 2000, except for fully assembled computers.
